div.p: Nunc de Spiritu Sancto Lombardus, I, d. 16, c. 1, n. 1 . After the Master determined about beginning of the temporal mission, now he determined about the different modes of this type of mission, and he divided it into two parts because in the first place he determines about the sensible and visible mode, in the second place about the invisible and internally perceptible. The second begins in distinction 17.

The first part is divided into two parts because in the first part he describes the visible mission of the Holy Spirit, in the second place he makes a comparison of this mission to the mission of the Son. The second begins at
sed prius Lombardus, I, d. 16, c. 1, n. 1 . And this is divided into three, for he shows in the first place that the Holy Spirit by reason of the mission is not referred to by the beginning of the sending, in the second place because the Son according to which man is less than the entire trinity and also himself, in the third place he shows how the Father is able to be called greater than then Son. The second begins at
notandum autem Lombardus, I, d. 16, c. 2, n. 1 . The third begins at
Hilarius Lombardus, I, d. 16, c. 2, n. 5
etc. And this is the division and opinion in general of the present distinction about which etc.
Whether the species in which the sent Holy Spirit appeared visibly were entities really changing created powers?

div.head: Principal arguments
div.p:
That not because then it would follow that the distinction of such visible species would imply proportionally a distinction of things known. The consequent is false because every cognition of the created intellect is placed in the genus of quality, but the species in which the Holy Spirit appear are not always in the same genus. This is clear from the the case of the dove and the fire. The consequence is clear because active causes differing in species acting naturally not freely cause specifically distinct actions. But these species are natural things, therefore, if they change the intellect by co-creating cognition in it, it follows that there will be a diversity of cognitions on account of a diversity of species. This is confirmed because in
II De anima
it is said that
to the distinction of objects it follows the distinction of acts and operations and from the distinction of operations follows the distinction powers Aristoteles, De anima, II, xxx .

In the second place, species existing in the created memory actuate the potency only mentally but not causally, therefore species existing extrinsically do not actuate causally or create change. The consequence holds because the argument does not apply less to one than to the other. And the antecedent is clear through
John of Ripa, quaestione 2, articulo 3, distinctione 2
Ripa, I, d. 2, a. 3, a. 3, xxx .

In the third place, the species in which the Holy Spirit appeared visibly were only imaginary and not real, therefore. The antecedent is clear because, according to
Blessed Augustine II De Trinitate, capitulo 5 , the visible mission of the Holy Spirit came for this reason
so that the heart of man understanding anew
by having seen through external things would be converted by understanding to the hidden deity
Augustinus, De Trinitate, II, c. 5, n. 10 (PL 42:XXX) . But the created intellect is moved by phantasms and imaginary species, therefore.

In opposition there is Gospel text In oppositum est textus evangelicus
Matthew 3 , where it is said
it descended in corporeal species Lucas 3:22 , therefore it was not phantasmatic or imaginary but had true and real body, therefore.

div.head: First conclusion
div.p:
The first conclusion: though the divine person appearing in a visible mission is able to be believed to create such a species without a second cause, nevertheless it possible that the blessed angels form such corporal species. The first part is clear because God able to do alone whatever he is able to with another in the genus of the efficient cause. The second part is proved because according to
Dionysius in On the angelic hierarchy ,
the law of divinity is to order the lower things through mediate things
Ps-Dionysius, De angelica hierarchia, XXX .

The first corollary: though the dove in which the Holy Spirit appeared visibly was formed by the angels, nevertheless only the humanity suppositionally united to Christy was only created by the three divine person The first is clear from the conclusion. The second is proved both since in the reason of dignity of that suppositional union it proper that this matter is immediately produced by God, and in the second place because it was formed in an instant. But this does not seem able to happen from a finite power, as I now supposed. This is also seen in Scripture
Matthew 1
what is born in her is from the Holy Spirit Matthew 1:20 . Again in Luke 1
The Holy Spirit will come upon you Lucas 1:35
etc.

Second corollary: though an angel is able to produce a corporeal sign of the temporal mission of the divine person, nevertheless the angel is not able in any way to effect the thing signified by this kind of sign. This is clear because this gratuitous gift added to the mind is produced by God alone.

Third corollary: just as the gift signified through a species is not subordinated to angelic activity, so not the angel but the divine person whose nature relates to this gift is said to appear or to be sent. This is clear because this gift signified through the species declares and denominates a sent person. And therefore, if this gift is a kind of wisdom, then it is able to be said that the Son is sent because wisdom is attributed to him. If it is a kind of love or mercy, then the Holy Spirit. If it is a kind of authority or power, then the Father is able to be said to appear, nevertheless he is not sent because he does not originate from anything.

For these things it would be possible to infer that, though the angels are not able to be creatures, nevertheless they are able to be producers of creatable things. The first part is clear because to create is for something to independently move through production from non being to being. The second part is clear because, as it has been said, this dove in the mystery of those things was produced, which was able to be created, indeed would be able to be recreated by God.

Second conclusion: the sensible species assisting extrinsically and intrinsically in the existence of the memory vitally changes the intellect and actuates it as an object and causally. This is clear, with respect to species extrinsically existing, through
Blessed Augustine in De vera religione, chapter 6 Augustinus, De vera religion, c. 6, xxx
and
II De Trinitate, chapter 4
Augustinus, De Trinitate, II, c. 4 . Again, it is clear through the
Philosopher in De memoria et reminiscentia , where he says
motion made by the sense or by the sensibile impresses just as some figure or sensible picture
Aristoteles, De memoria et reminiscentia, xxx . The second part is proved because, if such a species in existence of the memory intrinsiscally and does not change the potency as an object, then it would follows that there would not be a different between and habitual specie and a habitual concept in act, which is false because then someone having such a species actually would know it, which should not be said. This last consequence is clear because phantasm is a is the habitual word of the sensible species, as is clear through
Blessed Augustine where he is cited above
Vide supra.

The first corollary: it is stands that some vitally power changes and this is neither the vital form nor its formal act. This is clear because the voice and the fire and many other sensible species change the created intellect through the the senses, and nevertheless such species are vital forms, nor
is this change the formal act of these species, since it is the case that those things are and change nothing vitally.

The second corollary: it is the case that the intellect apprehends something and is moved vitally by the same thing, and the thing moving is really and seated in the intellect. This is clear through
Beatum Augustinum in De vera religione , where he says,
they apprehend vitally the son being absent and Rome or Carthage being distant Augustinus, De Vera Religione, XXX . And we have experience of this.

Third corollary: just as the intelligence is able to know a thing that is absent, so also is it possible to apprehend cogitively something not existing through a representing species . This is clear because just as one knows an absent and distant thing through a species abstractively, so concerning a thing not existing it is possible to have a species and through this to conceive something, therefore.

Third conclusion: though the dove in which the species of the sent Holy Spirit appeared was a real and true entity, nevertheless scripture expresses or asserts that some sign, in which the Holy Spirit appeared or was seen, that was not a real thing. The first part is clear through
Blessed Augustine II De Trinitate , where, speaking about the dove in which the Holy Spirit appeared during the baptism of Christ, he says
there is no doubt that it was real true body since scripture asserts that it descended in a bodily likeness
Augustinus, De Trinitate, II, c. XXX . The second part is clear
in the same book, in chapter 5
where concerning the tongue of fire on the day of Pentecost the Holy Spirit appeared he raises the question whether it was truly a thing or imaginary. The question unsolved is unsolved nor does he assert some part of it, but asserts as if a problem without an answer, nevertheless he concludes after saying many things
for they do not see tongues like fire
they are seen by them Act 2:3 . For in spiritual things we say it appeared to me and I have seen. But in those things which are shown to the eyes through an expressed bodily species, it is not accustomed to be said it appeared to me, but I have seen
Augustinus, De Trinitate, II, c. 6, n. 11 (PL 42:xxx) , therefore the conclusion is true.

The first corollary: that not every gratuitous sign demonstrating or putting forth that a creature is pleasing to God is created charity or a sacrament or infused habit gratifying the mind. This is clear because the mission of the Holy Spirit made under some visible sign is to cause a sign of sanctity to which an illative showing is sent, and nevertheless this bodily sign is not something of the aforementioned type, therefore.

Second corollary: it is the case that some person appears in a bodily sign and that this person is never sent or was sent. This is clear concerning the Father who appeared in a voice when Christ was baptized saying
here is my Son Matthaeus 3:17 , etc., and nevertheless nowhere in scripture is it read that he was sent because he originates from no other.

Third corollary: no thing in which the Holy Spirit appeared visibily was united it suppositionally. This is clear because the Holy Spirit it is never read tha the Holy Spirit was a dove, a tongue, or breath.

For this it is clear what should be said to the question, for it is possible to be said that some species in which the Holy Spirit appeared was a true and real entity, and some were only appearing and imaginary, nevertheless by all such instances was it possible for the sensitive or intellective created power to be changed or to be moved, etc.

Against the first conclusion it is argued, if it were true, then it follows that angels rather than the divine persons would be said to be sent and to appear or to have appeared. The consequent is false. The consequence is clear because, when angels form some body from the elements by applying something to active to passive things, it seems that the same thing appears in the formed body.

In the second place, the absolutely invisible is not able to be sent or to appear visibily without a fiction. But a fiction is repugnant to any divine person, therefore, etc. The consequence is clear because every divine person is absolutely invisible, according to
I Timothy ,
he inhabits a light inaccessible which no one sees
I Timothy 6:16 .

In the third place, against the second and third corollaries, a gratuitous gift is subordinated to the activity of the sacraments of the church, therefore it is able to be subordinated to angelic activity. The consequence holds
because an angel is more worthy, more perfect, and more active than any sacrament. The antecedent is clear because the sacrament of baptism confers and causes grace in the baptismal right.

Against the second conclusion, if this were true, it would follows that a species of this type or an object of this type would be caused. The consequent is false because the species of an object either represents more perfectly the species of memory or equally or less perfectly. Not the first because such a created species depends in its being and conserved by a species of the memory, and therefore as a consequence is less perfect. If it is said that it represents equally or less perfectly then such an act distinct from the species, which is equal or more sufficient for causing such a vital change. to such a vital change, would be posited in vain.

Against the first corollary, no change is vital which stands to be without this which is changed by the potency, but an objective causal change is of this type, therefore it is not in such a thing. The major is known. The minor is proved because it stands that some act is caused both informatively in the existing and through no superadded action, therefore.

In the third place against the second and third corollaries, only that which is vitally in a vital potency, is vitally apprehended, therefore whatever is apprehended in this way is present to the apprehending potency in this way. The consequence is valid, and the antecedent is proved because if follows that a is vitally apprehended by the intellective potency, therefore a is present to the intellective potency.

Against the third conclusion, if this were true, it would follows that the Holy Spirit in the dove in some special way would be beyond the mode by which God is in all things. But the consequent seems false because this would either be through an infusion of grade, and cannot be because it is not capable of grace, or through the unity of a supposite, and this cannot be as stated by the third corollary or through representation, and this cannot be because either such a representative sign would either be natural and universal, and thus the Holy Spirit would appear in some creature since everything is a vestige of the Trinity or this representative thing would be a gratuitous sign, and thus the Holy Spirit would be sent and appear in any sacrament. And the consequence is clear since the Holy Spirit is a gratuitious gift.

In the second place against the second part of the conclusion, it is repugnant to the highest truth that it shows itself through some fiction, therefore it is repugnant that the Holy Spirit manifested itself through imaginary and fantastical tongues of fire and not real tongues of fire. The consequence is clear because the appearances of a phantasm are fictions. The antecedent is clear because one showing themselves to be something which is not deceives the one to whom such a showing is made.

In the third place, it would follow that the Holy Spirit would not have appeared in those tongues unless to those Apostles and holy man who received the Holy Spirit. The consequent is false because they appeared to many others existing in the house with the Apostles.

To the first, the consequence is denied because, though an angel forms such a body, nevertheless it is not able to form nor create the signified gift though such a body, but God alone is able. Therefore this person alone is said to be sent or to appear namely, the one to whom the gift belongs, as is said in the third corollary.

To the second, it is said to the major that something is able to appear can be understood in two ways, in the first mode formally, intrinsecally, or with an intrinsic denomination suitable to itself, in the second mode with an extrinsic denomination. In the first mode I say that the appearance is repugnant to the divine person, but not in the second mode because in this way the divine person is said to appear visibly, not because it is seen, but because we see something through which we know that the Holy Spirit or another divine person is, in a special way, in the creature which such a sign is sent.

To the third, the consequence would be able to be denied because it does not follow that man is more perfect and more active than an ass, therefore man is able to produce an ass as an ass.
In the second place, it is said that though grace stands under the activity of the sacraments instrumentally and dispositively, nevertheless not principally and effectively.

To the first against the second conclusion, in the first place the consequence would be able
to be denied because such a causal reason would be able to be sufficiently terminated in this incomplex act of cognition or in this complex acting..

In the second place, the consequent would be able to be conceded, and to the disproof it is said that it is more perfect even when it is disproved. The consequence is denied because this likeness does not depend on this species as if a total cause, but only as a partial cause.

In the third place, it would be able to be said that, given that this likeness would represent itself imperfectly, nevertheless precise species of memory with such a created likeness would represent these species more perfectly than species of memory alone, since this likeness is not posited in vain.
To the second, the major is denied because such change does not proceed from such a species as if from a total effective cause.
In the second place, the minor would be able to be denied because with all the positive things required objective vital change is not able to be such that the potency is not changed.

In the third place, it would be able to be said that for something to change vitally it would be possible to be understood in two ways, in the first mode thus that the thing changing is vital, in the second mode that it is not in itself vitally changing, but nevertheless something vitally changes. In the first mode the the major premise has truth in somethings, but by taking vitally in the second mode the major is absolutely false.

To the third, the antecedent is denied because otherwise no existing thing outside the soul would be able to be perceived vitally, which is false. And say further that this consequence does not follow, a is vitally apprehended, therefore a is present to the apprehending potency.

In the second place, it would be able to be said that something existing in the vital potency is able to be taken in two ways, in the first mode in itself and proper being, in another mode in a species or its representative. In the first mode the antecedent should be denied, but in the second mode, with the preceding understanding, the consequence is denied.

To the first against the third conclusion, the consequence is conceded because it was there as if in a gratuitious sign showing the grace of the Holy Spirit, nevertheless this sign is not in any mode the cause of grace, though grace is reached through it, see
Thomas of Argentina, in distinction 16, article 1
Thomas de Argtina, I, c. 16, a. 1, xxx , where he posits a triple sign.

To the second, to the antecedent it is said that if fiction is taken for some imaginary revelation or representation, thus I say that it is not repugnant to God to revel himself to creatures in this way, for the prophets had knowledge of many things through such imaginary visions, as is clear in their books. But if fiction is taken for deception, in this case the antecedent is conceded, but the consequence is denied.
To the third, it is denied because this sign by divine strength was able to be multiplied in the fantasy of everyone one to whom these tongues appeared..

To the first in the opposition, the consequence is conceded and the consequence of the disproof is denied because the perfection of cognition is not always quantified precisely with respect to the perfection of the known object or the thing vitally changing the potency objectively, as the argument seems to suggest. To the other arguments it is clear what should be said from what has been said.

Nunc de spiritu sancto Lombardus, I, d. 16, c. 1, n. 1 . This distinction contains six conclusions. The first is that there is a double procession of the Holy Spirit, an eternal one which proceeds from the Father and the Son and not from itself, another temporal one which is called mission or giving. And the latter is twofold, one visible when it appears, as at the day of Pentecost or in the baptism of Christ in the species of a dove, another invisible which is given to the minds of the faithful. And in this manner it is given through a double giving, not only by the Father and the Son, but also by itself.
The second conclusion: that the Son also is said to be sent in two ways, in one mode visibly when he appeared in the flesh, in another mode when he is perceived by pious minds.
Third conclusion: though the Holy Spirit is not seen visibly in its own nature, nevertheless it is sent and this occurs through a visible species.

Fourth conclusion: that the Holy Spirit is not more greatly in those creatures in which it is said to appear that in other things, but it is shown through these things because the Holy Spirit is in these things through sanctifications and grace to which these species or created things come.

Fifth conclusion: that the Son assumed the nature in which appeared differently than the Holy Spirit because the Son assumed it through the hypostatic union, but not the Holy Spirit,
and the Son accepted man and humanity so that he would become man, but the Holy Spirit did not accept the form of a dove so that it would become a dove. And therefore the Son is said more the Father according to its accepted nature, but not the Holy Spirit.

Sixth conclusion: that the Son of God according to the form of God is equal to the Father, but according to the form of man is less than the Father and the Holy Spirit and also himself inasmuch as he is God.

Seventh conclusion: that according to Hilary
the Father is greater than the Son, nevertheless he is not less than the Father, for the one giving is greater, but he is not now less to whom one being is given.
XXX
Note nevertheless that the word greater does not note essential inequality, but only the notional authority of the origin because the Father originates the Son, therefore the Son is equal to the Father in actual reality because every perfections which the Father has, the Son has. But the Father is said to be greater than the Son in the mode of having because the Son has this perfection from the Father and the not the reverse. Also note that Hilary does not concede that the Son is less than the Father both because minority seems to convey indignity and because he wishes to remove from the heretics the defense and occasion of errors.
